awd_titl_txt: Real-Time Sensing of Neurotransmitters From Stem Cell-derived Neural Interface Using Hybrid Graphene-Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Neurotransmitters are one of the most critical biomolecules in the brain. They play a vital role in preserving neurophysiological processes such as cognition, memory, and behavior. For example, the abnormal levels of neurotransmitters may result in severe neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, and Huntington's disease. In the case of Parkinson's disease, most patients have lost more than 80% of their production of dopamine neurotransmitter. Stem cell-based therapy to create dopamine-producing (dopaminergic) neurons that can be implanted into patients has emerged as a promising approach for treating Parkinson's disease. The functionality of stem cell-derived dopaminergic neurons can be confirmed by the detection of dopamine. The proposed biosensing system has the capability of real-time monitoring of stem cell differentiation by detecting neurotransmitters.  It will accelerate the development of stem cell therapies by removing some bottlenecks in current stem cell therapies. Moreover, the proposed biosensor will be an excellent sensing platform to advance research and development in regenerative medicine and neuroscience.

The scientific goal of this proposal is to investigate how stem cells can generate a neural interface with functional neurons by detecting neurotransmitters selectively and effectively. Conventional neurotransmitter detection methods suffer from non-specific sensing and lack of in situ analysis. Addressing current challenges in the detection of neurotransmitters, a novel in situ nano-biosensor using graphene oxide-covered nanostructure arrays as a platform to real-time monitor mature neuronal differentiation of stem cells will be developed by detecting the secreted neurotransmitters in a noninvasive manner. For this purpose, the proposal focuses on the synthesis of chemically well-defined graphene oxide-nanostructures and the development of graphene-based hybrid nanoelectrode arrays to generate stable and reproducible signals. The developed novel graphene-based hybrid nanoelectrode arrays detect dopamine molecules selectively and sensitively using surface-enhanced Raman scattering technique. Raman dye (graphene oxide)-labeled aptamers targeting dopamine molecules are attached to the surface of graphene oxide-covered nanostructure arrays through the pi-pi interactions, resulting in a Raman enhancement from the graphene oxide nanostructures. The loss of binding affinity between nucleotides and the Raman dye (malachite green molecules)-labeled aptamers after the dye-labeled aptamers reacted with dopamine will consequently decrease the Raman signal for quantitative analysis. The whole processes enable the detection of low concentration of dopamine in the neural interface. Upon successful completion, the proposed nano-biosensing system will facilitate the study of a biological phenomenon by monitoring cell secretions from complex biological matrices. The proposal takes advantage of the graphene functionalized surface and the highly selective bio-recognition elements to fabricate a novel hybrid graphene-nanostructure-based real-time sensing system to act as a multi-purpose sensor platform for the detection of a variety of molecules. Given the challenges of in situ detection of neurotransmitters at the single cell level, this surface-enhanced Raman scattering-based detection method can represent a unique tool for investigating single-cell mechanisms associated with dopamine, or other neurotransmitters, and their roles in neurological processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to develop an advanced biosensing platform for real-time detection of neurotransmitters, with a focus on dopamine, using a graphene-gold hybrid nanoarray (AP-GONA). Neurotransmitters such as dopamine are essential for brain communication, and abnormal release patterns are associated with neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson’s. Understanding the release of these molecules is crucial for advancing treatments in neurological disorders. The project developed a non-invasive, sensitive method to detect neurotransmitter release from stem cell-derived neurons, which has wide-reaching implications for research and therapeutic applications.

The core of this technology is the AP-GONA biosensor, which was fabricated using laser interference lithography (LIL) to create a homogeneous, large-scale nanoarray. This nanoarray was then modified with graphene oxide and gold nanoparticles to enhance its sensitivity. The ability of the platform to detect neurotransmitters was demonstrated using Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS). SERS amplifies the signals produced when dopamine interacts with the graphene nanoarray, allowing for highly sensitive detection at the cellular level. This innovative approach enabled the detection of neurotransmitter release from single dopaminergic neurons, providing a new way to study neurochemical dynamics at the single-cell level, which was previously unattainable with conventional methods.

One of the key applications of this platform was in monitoring the differentiation of neural stem cells into dopaminergic neurons. Over a 20-day period, the platform continuously tracked dopamine release from these cells. The AP-GONA biosensor provided real-time data on how dopamine secretion increased as the stem cells differentiated into neurons, offering insights into the progression of neuronal development. These observations were validated by conventional immunostaining techniques, which showed corresponding changes in cell markers, confirming that the AP-GONA biosensor is highly effective for studying cellular differentiation processes.

The broader impact of this research is substantial. This biosensor represents a significant advancement in the field of neuroscience by providing a tool for non-invasive, real-time detection of neurotransmitters at the single-cell level. The ability to monitor neurotransmitter release is crucial for studying diseases like Parkinson’s, where dopamine dysfunction is a central issue. In the long term, the AP-GONA platform could play a vital role in developing treatments for neurodegenerative diseases by enabling researchers to understand better how neurotransmitter dynamics are altered in these conditions.

Moreover, the AP-GONA platform is versatile. Its design allows for the detection of other biological molecules beyond dopamine. For instance, the system was adapted to detect nucleic acids using a CRISPR/Cas12a-based approach, achieving sensitivity down to the atto-molar level. This means that the platform could be useful in diagnostic applications for viral infections, cancer biomarkers, or other molecular targets, making it a flexible tool for both biomedical research and clinical diagnostics.

The research conducted during this project also provided significant opportunities for training and professional development. Two postdoctoral fellows and two graduate students were trained as primary operators for the LIL and SERS techniques used to develop and test the AP-GONA platform. These students gained valuable experience in nanotechnology, biosensing, and data analysis, which are critical for advancing careers in biomedical engineering and nanotechnology. The project also involved additional graduate and undergraduate students, who were introduced to cutting-edge techniques in nanofabrication and biosensing.

Looking toward the future, the AP-GONA platform has immense potential for further development. One promising area of research is expanding the platform’s ability to detect multiple neurotransmitters or biomarkers simultaneously. By integrating machine learning algorithms, researchers could analyze complex datasets generated by the platform to uncover new insights into neural communication or stem cell differentiation. This could lead to innovations in personalized medicine, where the platform might be used to monitor an individual’s cellular activity and optimize treatments for neurological disorders. Additionally, the system could be further developed for regenerative medicine applications, where real-time monitoring of stem cell differentiation is crucial for ensuring the success of therapies designed to repair damaged neural tissue.

In summary, this project has successfully developed an innovative, highly sensitive biosensing platform for real-time monitoring of neurotransmitter release from neural cells. The AP-GONA system not only offers new insights into cellular processes but also holds broad potential for applications in disease research, diagnostics, and regenerative medicine. Its versatility and adaptability make it a valuable tool in neuroscience and beyond, with the potential to significantly impact how we understand and treat neurological diseases.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2024
Modified by: Kibum Lee
